body.p: A Kentucky attorney, farmer, soldier, and politician. Graduated from Transylvania University law department and admitted to the bar in 1846. Practiced law in Paris, Kentucky. Married to Lucy Ann Frances Blythe Simms. Father of Lucy Blythe Simms, William E. Simms, Jr., and Edward Francis Simms. Served as a captain in the Mexican War. Elected as a member of the Kentucky House of Representatives in 1849 and 1851. Served the Eighth Congressional District of Kentucky as a Democratic Party member of the United States House of Representative from 1859 to 1861. Served as a colonel in the Confederate Army and as a lieutenant colonel in the Provisional Army of the Confederate States in the First Battalion, Kentucky Cavalry. Resigned on February 17, 1862 to serve as a Kentucky senator in the Congress of the Confederate States of America. Served in both the First and Second Confederate Congresses from 1862 to 1865.
